body.p: Marko Ampuja recently earned his PhD in media and communication studies from the University of Helsinki. He is currently a university instructor at the University of Helsinki in the Department of Social Research where he teaches on the International Master’s Degree Programme in Media and Global Communication. His fields of interest are social theory, critical theory, political economy of the media, globalization and media theory.

R.A. Dello Buono is Professor and Chair of the Sociology Department at Manhattan College. He is co-author (with Ximena de la Barra) of Latin America after the Neoliberal Debacle: Another Region is Possible (Rowman and Littlefield, 2009); co-editor (with Graham Cassano) of Crisis, Politics and Critical Sociology (Brill Academic, 2010); and co-editor (with José Bell Lara) of Imperialism, Neoliberalism and Social Struggles in Latin America (Haymarket, 2009).

Dwight Haase is an Assistant Professor in the Department of Sociology and Anthropology at the University of Toledo. Before receiving his PhD in sociology at the University of Wisconsin-Madison in 2006, he worked and conducted research with microfinance institutions in South Asia, Central America and the USA. His research interests also include globalization and social movements.

Jacob Lesniewski is a Doctoral Candidate at the University of Chicago’s School of Social Service Administration. His dissertation is an ethnographic study of a workers’ center in Chicago and attempts to better understand how workers’ centers build power for low-wage workers. Jacob has spent significant time studying and working within the labor movement in Chicago and beyond. He began his career as a community development worker in Guatemala and has worked as an organizer in various Chicago neighborhoods and campaigns. He has taught graduate and undergraduate students at the University of Chicago and Wheaton (IL) College and served as the internship coordinator for the Human Rights Program at the University of Chicago.

Eugene Dili Liow received his MA in social science in sociology in 2009 from the Department of Sociology at the National University of Singapore. Currently a research assistant cum project coordinator at the same department, his areas of interest are primarily in class, political economy, globalization and social theory. He is currently reworking and updating his dissertation on the working class in Singapore in order to prepare it for publication.

Andy Mathers is a Senior Lecturer in Sociology & Criminology in the Department for Health and Applied Social Sciences at UWE Bristol. He is the author of Struggling for a Social Europe: Neoliberal Globalisation, the EU and the Birth of a European Social Movement published by Ashgate and the co-author of The Crisis of Social Democratic Trade Unionism in Western: The Search for Alternatives also published by Ashgate. His current research interest is mainly on the revitalisation of the labour movement in the context of the wider mobilisation of resistance to neoliberal globalisation.

Silvina M. Romano has a PhD in political science and is currently at the Center for Advanced Studies and the Faculty of Law at Córdoba National University; she is a graduate in history and in social communication at Córdoba National University. She was awarded a scholarship by the Latin American Council and did her doctorate studies under the auspices of the National Council on Technical and Scientific Research (CONICET, Argentina). She subsequently has done work on a postdoctoral scholarship from CONICET. She was a member of the CLACSO Group on Studies of the USA and also part of a research team on ‘Multiculturalism, Migration and Inequality in Latin America’ at the Center for Advanced Studies, Córdoba National University. Her work over the last six years has focused on relationships between the USA and Latin America during the Cold War; democracy in the USA; integration, development and dependency in Latin America; and migration and underdevelopment.

Darío Salinas Figueredo is a sociologist who graduated from the Chile Catholic University. His master’s degree was completed at the Latin American Faculty of Social Sciences (FLACSO) and his doctoral degree is from the Ibero-American University. He is a full time professor and researcher for the Ibero-American University of México (UIA) in México City, where he coordinates the research program and the seminar on ‘Governability and Political Institutions in Latin America’. He is coordinator and research associate of the Latin American Council of Social Sciences (CLACSO) Working Group ‘United States and Latin America in the New Hemispheric Dynamic’ and coordinator for the Latin American Sociology Association (ALAS) Working Group ‘State Reform, Governability and Democracy’. His numerous publications include: Democratización y tensiones de gobernabilidad en América Latina (2006); Vicisitudes de la democracia. Entre el peso del modelo y los límites de la política en Chile (2007); La democracia de América Latina en las tendencias regionales y hemisféricas (2008) and Procesos políticos, crisis y tendencias regionales actuales en América Latina (2010).

Kim Scipes is an Assistant Professor of Sociology at Purdue University North Central in Westville, Indiana. He has published widely on labor, both domestically and globally, and is the author of KMU: Building Genuine Trade Unionism in the Philippines, 1980–1994 (Quezon City, Metro Manila: New Day Publishers, 1996) and AFL-CIO’s Secret War against Developing Country Workers: Solidarity or Sabotage? (Lanham, MD: Lexington Books, 2010).

Adrián Sotelo Valencia is a professor and researcher at the Center for Latin American Studies, Faculty of Political and Social Sciences, National Autonomous University of Mexico. He is a member of the National System of Researchers (SNI) of the National Council of Science and Technology (CONACyT) of Mexico and has recently been named Honorary Professor at the Universidad Ricardo Palma of Peru. He is author of over 14 books and numerous other writings on the sociology of work in Latin America, dependency theory and structural problems of Latin American development. His latest books include: A reestruturação do mundo do trabalho. superexploração e novos paradigmas de organização do trabalho, Editora da Universidade Federal de Uberlândia, MG, Brazil (2009); and Crisis capitalista y desmedida del valor: un enfoque desde los Grundrisse, Editorial Itaca-UNAM-FCPYS, Mexico (2010). A collection of his journal articles and other pieces can be accessed at http://www.redem.buap.mx/

Luis Suárez Salazar completed his two doctorates at the University of Havana and is visiting professor at the Instituto Superior de Relaciones Internacionales ‘Raul Rosa García’ and at the Faculty of Philosophy and History at the University of Havana. He has published numerous books, articles and essays, among which are included: Cuba: ¿Aislamiento o reinserción en un mundo cambiado? (1997); El siglo XXI: Posibilidades y desafíos para la Revolución Cubana (2001); Madre América: Un siglo de violencia y dolor (2004); Un siglo de terror en América Latina (2006); Las relaciones interamericanas: continuidades y cambios (2008) and La estrategia revolucionaria del Che: Una mirada desde los primeros lustros del siglo XXI (2009).

Martin Upchurch is Professor of International Employment Relations at Middlesex University, London, UK, where he is convenor of the Global Work and Employment (GWEp) project. He is the co-author of New Unions, New Workplaces (Routledge, 2003), The Realities of Partnership at Work, published by Palgrave Macmillan (2008) and The Crisis of Social Democratic Trade Unionism in Western Europe: The Search for Alternatives, published by Ashgate (2009).
